tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is a psalm that Asaph wrote." See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:053:001|53:1]].

tn.ref: my feet almost slipped; my feet almost slipped out from under me
tn.text: The psalmist speaks of being unable to trust God and wanting to sin as if he had almost fallen while walking on a slippery path. AT: "I almost stopped trusting in God; I was almost guilty of committing a great sin against him" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: I was envious of the arrogant
tn.text: "I envied the arrogant" or "I did not want arrogant people to have the good things that they had"
The adjective "arrogant" can be translated as a noun phrase. AT: "arrogant people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
The word "prosperity" can be translated as a verb. AT: "how the wicked have so many good things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The adjective "wicked" can be translated as a noun phrase. AT: "wicked people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
Asaph begins to describe how he sometimes wants to complain to God about those who are "arrogant" and "wicked" ([[:en:bible:notes:psa:073:001|73:3]]).
The words "burdens" is a metonym for the struggles of daily life (need for food, shelter, clothing, and health). (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: they are not afflicted like other men
tn.text: "they do not suffer the way other people do"
Asaph continues to describe how he sometimes wants to complain to God about those who are "arrogant" and "wicked" ([[:en:bible:notes:psa:073:001|73:3]]).

tn.ref: Pride adorns them like a necklace around their neck; violence clothes them like a robe
tn.text: This means the wicked show everyone how proud and violent they are as if they were wearing a necklace or beautiful robe. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This refers to things that rich and important people wear.
a chain usually made of gold or jewels that goes around the neck

tn.ref: Out of such blindness comes sin
tn.text: Because they are like blind people who cannot see where they are going, they sin without knowing it. Being blind is a metaphor for a person being unable to see how wicked he is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: evil thoughts pass through their hearts
tn.text: Here the psalmist describes people's thoughts as if they were people. He also describes the inner beings of wicked people as if they were a building in which those people could walk. AT: "in their inner beings they are always thinking about more evil things to do" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Asaph continues to describe how he sometimes wants to complain to God about those who are "arrogant" and "wicked" ([[:en:bible:notes:psa:073:001|73:3]]).
Whom they mock can be stated clearly. AT: "They mock God and his people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: They set their mouth against the heavens
tn.text: Here the word "heavens" is a metonym for God, who lives in the heavens. AT: "They speak against God, who is in the heavens" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"speak strongly" or "speak with purpose" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: their tongues march through the earth
tn.text: The word "tongues" is a metonym for the people themselves. Possible meanings are 1) "they go through the earth saying bad things about God" or "they go everywhere and boast about themselves."  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Asaph continues to describe how he sometimes wants to complain to God about those who are "arrogant" and "wicked" ([[:en:bible:notes:psa:073:001|73:3]]).
Possible meanings are 1) "God's people love the wicked people" or "the wicked people return to this place"
Possible meanings are 1) "God's people listen gladly to the words of the wicked people" or 2) "the wicked people have plenty of food to eat and wine to drink"
the wicked people say

tn.ref: How does God know? Is there knowledge with the Most High?
tn.text: These rhetorical questions are to show contempt for God. These questions can be translated as statements. AT: "Surely God does not know what we are doing. The Most High has no knowledge of it." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

In verses 13 and 14, Asaph continues to describe how he sometimes wants to complain to God about those who are "arrogant" and "wicked" ([[:en:bible:notes:psa:073:001|73:3]]). In verse 15 he begins to talk about what he is really thinking.
The word "I" refers to Asaph.
Asaph speaks of guarding his heart as if he were guarding a city or building against enemies. AT: "I have kept my thoughts pure" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The writer speaks of his purity as if he had washed his hands with innocence instead of with water. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:026:006|26:6]]. AT: "my actions have remained pure" or "I have washed my hands to show that I am innocent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"always" or "every day"
"You have made me suffer." See how "they are not afflicted" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:073:004|73:5]].
"I have been ... punished"

tn.ref: If I had said, "I will say these things," then I would have betrayed this generation of your children
tn.text: This hypothetical situation did not happen. AT: "I never said, 'I will say these things,' so I did not betray this generation of your children" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
The good things that happen to "the wicked" ([[:en:bible:notes:psa:073:004|73:4]]-[[:en:bible:notes:psa:073:010|12]]).
"what happens to wicked people when they die" (UDB) or "how wicked people die"
The word "them" refers to the wicked.
"unsafe or unstable ground." See how "slipped" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:073:001|73:2]].

tn.ref: How they become a wilderness in a moment
tn.text: The word "wilderness" is a metaphor for a person who has lost everything good. AT: "How quickly they are destroyed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: like a dream after one wakes up
tn.text: The wicked will last no longer than what a person sees in a dream. It disappears as soon as the person wakes up. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
The word "heart" is a metonym for a person's thoughts and feelings. AT: "I was very sad"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The psalmist speaks of emotional pain as if it were physical pain. AT: "I felt like someone had wounded me" with a knife or arrow. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize how little he knew. AT: "very ignorant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"understood nothing"
This "you" refers to God.
The word "I" here represents Asaph. The word "you" here represents God.
This shows an intimate relationship with God that offers stability and security. AT: "You hold me close" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Possible meanings are 1) "put me where people will honor me" or 2) "honor me by taking me to where you are." See how "receive me" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:049:014|49:15]].

tn.ref: Whom have I in heaven but you?
tn.text: You can translate this as a statement. AT: "There is no one for me in heaven but you" or "You are the only one I have in heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"among the gods" or "among the supernatural beings"
"no human being"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These two phrases share similar meanings. Together they represent the whole person. AT: "My body and my mind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
Asaph continues to talk about God.

tn.ref: Those who are far from you
tn.text: Here the idea of staying far from God is compared to being unwilling to obey him. AT: "Those who do not want to obey you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The writer speaks of Yahweh as if he were a place to which a person could flee for safety. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
